content_1: . Tests at AFSSA (French Agency for Food Safety) laboratory confirmed that turkeys on a breeder farm in northeastern France were infected with the pandemic H1N1 (2009) virus. The farmers became concerned about the health of the flock when they noticed a significant drop in egg production. Approximately 3,000 of the 8,600 birds on the farm had the illness, but there were no mortalities, and the sick birds recovered fully. The farm will continue to be quarantined for 7 days after clinical signs disappear as a preventative measure. The origin of the outbreak is unknown.
content_2: . On January 12, a worker on a farm in Yamagata prefecture reported to the Livestock Hygiene Service Center that some of the pigs had symptoms such as poor appetite, fever, and cough. The farm holds 2,445 pigs, 164 of which were ill. They took samples from ten of the sick pigs and four of the samples tested positive for pandemic H1N1 (2009) virus at the National Institute of Animal Health. The farm is voluntarily restraining the movement of the animals to prevent the spread of the disease. Some workers had been sick before the outbreak, and an epidemiological investigation is underway.
content_3: . An outbreak of H5N1 bird flu occurred in 250 birds from a farm of 1,182 in Rajshahi division on January 4. The rest of the flock was culled and the premises were disinfected to prevent the spread of the disease. Samples tested positive for H5N1 bird flu on January 17 at the Bangladesh Livestock Research Institute. The origin of the outbreak is unknown.
content_4: . Pamekasan regency’s veterinary office destroyed 270 chickens infected with H5N1 bird flu to prevent the disease from spreading in East Java. Chickens in Pademawu Timur village had been dying suddenly. On January 11, veterinary officials came to the village to test the birds and found them positive for H5N1.
content_5: . Four hundred ducks from a flock of 550 in Thach Quy ward in Ha Tinh province died between January 17 and 19. Samples were taken by the provincial Veterinary Department and tested positive for H5N1. The remaining ducks were culled and birds in the surrounding area have been quarantined as a preventative measure. The Department of Animal Health announced on January 24 that 400 ducks and 600 chickens in Cam Xuyen District in Ha Tinh province have died of H5N1 bird flu. The province People’s Committee has banned the sale, slaughter, and transport of poultry in the affected regions. Bird flu has been confirmed in Thang Hung and Thanh Yen communes in Dien Bien province, where approximately 14,400 birds have died. Staff from the Dien Bien District Medical Centre disinfected the premises and taught local residents how to prevent an outbreak.
content_6:
(LPAI). In Changhua County, approximately 7,000 chickens from a farm of 50,000 died of H5N2 bird flu. According to a report, no sick chickens were sold on the market. "The bird flu epidemic in the farm has been under control. All staff and animals have been isolated but we are not going to kill all chickens in the farm," said Chou-Che Kuo, head of the prevention unit of Changhua county.
